![West Five Royal Tombs [UNESCO World Heritage] (Í≥†Ïñë ÏÑúÏò§Î¶â [Ïú†ÎÑ§Ïä§ÏΩî ÏÑ∏Í≥ÑÎ¨∏ÌôîÏú†ÏÇ∞])](/2022-09-10-1662799677506/1589188_image2_1.webp) ## Overview > West Five Royal Tombs is the second largest royal burial site of the Joseon dynasty after Donggureung Royal Tombs. In Korean, the burial mounds of kings and queens are named reung or neung, while those of kings‚Äô parents, crown princes and princesses are called won, and the burial mounds of other princes and princesses are called myo.

West Five Royal Tombs consists of Gyeongneung (the tomb of posthumously designated rulers, King Deokjong and Queen Sohye), Changneung (the tomb of King Yejong, the 8th ruler, and Queen Ansun), Hongneung (the tomb of Queen Jeongseong, a consort to King Yeongjo, the 21st ruler), Ingneung (the tomb of Queen Ingyeong, a consort to King Sukjong) and Myeongneung (the tomb of King Sukjong, the 19th ruler, and his two wives, Queen Inhyeon and Queen Inwon).

In addition to the five reungs in West Five Royal Tombs, there are three wons. These include Sunchangwon (the tombs of Crown Prince Sunhoe and Crown Princess Gonghoebin), Sugyeongwon (the tomb of King Yeongjo‚Äôs concubine, Yeongbin) and Yeonghoewon (King Injo‚Äôs son, Crown Prince Sohyeon and Crown Princess Minhoebin). Also, Daebinmyo, the grave of Janghuibin who was King Sukjong‚Äôs concubine and King Gyeongjong‚Äôs mother, was recently moved to the burial site. ## Intro | | | | - | - | |infocenter:|‚Ä¢ 1330 Travel Hotline: +82-2-1330
(Korean, English, Japanese, Chinese)

* Free admission: Preschoolers (ages 6 & younger), senior citizens (ages 65 & older), all visitors the last Wednesday of every month, visitors wearing hanbok| |Restrooms:|Available| |Parking Fees:|Free| |Interpretation Services Offered:|Available (* Reservations must be made in advance.)| ## Detail Image ![/2022-09-10-1662799677506/1589186_image2_1.webp](/2022-09-10-1662799677506/1589186_image2_1.webp) ![/2022-09-10-1662799677506/1589187_image2_1.webp](/2022-09-10-1662799677506/1589187_image2_1.webp) ![/2022-09-10-1662799677506/1589189_image2_1.webp](/2022-09-10-1662799677506/1589189_image2_1.webp) ![/2022-09-10-1662799677506/1589190_image2_1.webp](/2022-09-10-1662799677506/1589190_image2_1.webp) ![/2022-09-10-1662799677506/1589191_image2_1.webp](/2022-09-10-1662799677506/1589191_image2_1.webp) ![/2022-09-10-1662799677506/1589192_image2_1.webp](/2022-09-10-1662799677506/1589192_image2_1.webp) ![/2022-09-10-1662799677506/1589193_image2_1.webp](/2022-09-10-1662799677506/1589193_image2_1.webp) ## Contact - [‚òéÔ∏è+82-2-359-0090](tel:+8223590090) - [üè†royaltombs.cha.go.kr](http://royaltombs.cha.go.kr/) ```googleMap latitude: 37.6236101060 longitude: 126.9007820485 title: 334-32, Seooreung-ro, Deogyang-gu, Goyang-si, Gyeonggi-do ``` ## Directions [Subway + Bus]
Nokbeon Station (Seoul Subway Line 3), Exit 4.
Take Bus No. 9701 or 702A and get off at Seooreung Entrance Bus Stop.

data.title: West Five Royal Tombs [UNESCO World Heritage] (Í≥†Ïñë ÏÑúÏò§Î¶â [Ïú†ÎÑ§Ïä§ÏΩî ÏÑ∏Í≥ÑÎ¨∏ÌôîÏú†ÏÇ∞])
data.description:
West Five Royal Tombs is the second largest royal burial site of the Joseon dynasty after Donggureung Royal Tombs. In Korean, the burial mounds of kings and queens are named reung or neung, while those of kings‚Äô parents, crown princes and princesses are called won, and the burial mounds of other princes and princesses are called myo.

West Five Royal Tombs consists of Gyeongneung (the tomb of posthumously designated rulers, King Deokjong and Queen Sohye), Changneung (the tomb of King Yejong, the 8th ruler, and Queen Ansun), Hongneung (the tomb of Queen Jeongseong, a consort to King Yeongjo, the 21st ruler), Ingneung (the tomb of Queen Ingyeong, a consort to King Sukjong) and Myeongneung (the tomb of King Sukjong, the 19th ruler, and his two wives, Queen Inhyeon and Queen Inwon).

In addition to the five reungs in West Five Royal Tombs, there are three wons. These include Sunchangwon (the tombs of Crown Prince Sunhoe and Crown Princess Gonghoebin), Sugyeongwon (the tomb of King Yeongjo‚Äôs concubine, Yeongbin) and Yeonghoewon (King Injo‚Äôs son, Crown Prince Sohyeon and Crown Princess Minhoebin). Also, Daebinmyo, the grave of Janghuibin who was King Sukjong‚Äôs concubine and King Gyeongjong‚Äôs mother, was recently moved to the burial site.
data.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Seolmaejae Recreational Forest (ÏÑ§Îß§Ïû¨ÏûêÏó∞Ìú¥ÏñëÎ¶º)
dataList.description: Seolmaejae Recreational Forest is located around Seolmaejae Pass, named for the apricot blossoms ('mae') that would bloom in the snow ('seol')-filled pass ('jae'). The forest is only an hour's drive out of Seoul, making it easily accessible for people looking to escape the city. The forest offers sections of pine trees, maple trees, royal azalea, and more beautiful flora, all visible along the various hiking paths. The park also connects with Yumyeongsan and Yongmunsan Mountains, and is close to Yongcheongyegok and Yumyeongsan Valleys.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Seolbongsan Mountain (ÏÑ§Î¥âÏÇ∞)
dataList.description: Seolbongsan Mountain (ÏÑ§Î¥âÏÇ∞, 394 m) dominates the western portion of Icheon City. It has also been called Bugaksan Mountain and Muhaksan Mountain since the mountain resembles a crane with its wings spread open. Although the mountain is not rugged and maintains a well kept walking trail, it has many intriguing rock formations. There are as many as eight natural springs from which clear water gushes, and there are also Buddhist temples and relics scattered across the mountain. There are other attractions to see and enjoy as well, such as Seolbong Park, which was established at the opening of the World Ceramic Exhibition, as well as the municipal museum.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Seolbong Park (ÏÑ§Î¥âÍ≥µÏõê)
dataList.description: Nestled at the foot of Seolbongsan Mountain in Icheon, Seolbong Park is the venue for the Gyeonggi International Ceramic Biennale, Icheon Ceramic Festival, and Icheon Rice Cultural Festival. Outside of festival periods, the park also serves as a rest area for locals, with a wide lake in the center, walking paths, and gardens. Cerapia, a ceramic themed park located within Seolbong Park, offers hands-on programs for visitors to experience ceremics.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Sangdong Lake Park (ÏÉÅÎèôÌò∏ÏàòÍ≥µÏõê)
dataList.description: Sangdong Lake Park is the largest park in Bucheon. A 2.5-kilometer promenade runs along a man-made lake, providing a refreshing and cool environment for a light exercise. The park also offers a beautiful sight year round thanks to the seasonal flowers that decorate the area. Some of the park's main facilities include a fountain, park square, wildflower garden, and sports facilities.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Samsung Innovation Museum (ÏÇºÏÑ± Ïù¥ÎÖ∏Î≤†Ïù¥ÏÖò ÎÆ§ÏßÄÏóÑ)
dataList.description: Samsung Innovation Museum is an electronic industrial museum run by Samsung, a major global company based in Korea. The museum mainly consists of three sections. Visitors can learn about the history of Korea's electronic industry, as well as the past, present and future of the semiconductor, display and mobile industries, where Samsung made great achievements. The museum also runs an education facility called Children's Display Research Institute.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Provence Village (ÌîÑÎ°úÎ∞©Ïä§ ÎßàÏùÑ)
dataList.description:
Provence Village is a themed village that began with the opening of a chic French restaurant in 1996. It has expanded to include a famous bakery cafe, Italian and Korean restaurants, shops, colorful murals, a beautiful garden, and romantic lighting displays in the evenings.

Each unique shop is connected to other shops in the village. An art studio offers a wide array of dishes used in cafes and restaurants in the village; the Living Gallery not only decorates Provence Village, but also makes decorative items such as hand-painted ceramics, available for purchase; and the European bakery boasts fresh, delicious breads. Each shop is an independent unit with a unique design concept. The Living Gallery offers shops selling ceramics, flowers, and herbs, while the Fashion Gallery consists of shops offering clothing, accessories, and interior design items. The Herb Garden hosts a wide array of cultural events and performances for visitors throughout the year.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Pocheon Sansawon  (Ìè¨Ï≤ú ÏÇ∞ÏÇ¨Ïõê)
dataList.description: Pocheon Sansawon is a museum of traditional Korean liquor, mainly home-brewed liquor. Several rows of liquor crock pots in Sewollang, the garden in Sansawon, create a magnificent view. Old materials and books about the history of Korea's liquor culture attract visitors. After touring the museum, visitors can try non-sterilized liquor of Baesangmyeon Brewery and join activity programs for making home-brewed liquor, fruit-based liquor, seasonal liquor, and more.
dataList.author: korea-tour
